metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: The application of Faraday's laws and stoichiometry to determine the quantity of electrolytic reactant and product, and the current or time required to either use a particular quantity of reactant or produce a particular quantity of product

faraday_constant_definition.name: Faraday's Constant
faraday_constant_definition.correct: Faraday's constant is the charge carried by one mole of electrons, equal to 96 500 coulombs per mole.

96 500 J mol⁻¹.error: Wrong unit. Faraday's constant measures charge, not energy.
96 500 J mol⁻¹.fix: F is in coulombs per mole (C mol⁻¹), not joules per mole.
96 500 J mol⁻¹.action: Charge is measured in coulombs (C). Energy is in joules (J). Different quantities.

9650 C mol⁻¹.error: Missing a zero. The value is 96 500, not 9650.
9650 C mol⁻¹.fix: F = 96 500 C mol⁻¹. Remember: nearly 100 000 coulombs per mole of electrons.
9650 C mol⁻¹.action: Write it out: ninety-six thousand five hundred. Check your data sheet.

6.02 × 10²³ C mol⁻¹.error: That's Avogadro's number, not Faraday's constant.
6.02 × 10²³ C mol⁻¹.fix: Avogadro's number tells you how many particles in a mole. F tells you the charge per mole of electrons.
6.02 × 10²³ C mol⁻¹.action: F = Avogadro's number × charge on one electron. They're related but different.

1.60 × 10⁻¹⁹ C mol⁻¹.error: That's the charge on ONE electron, not one mole of electrons.
1.60 × 10⁻¹⁹ C mol⁻¹.fix: F = 96 500 C mol⁻¹. The charge on one electron is 1.60 × 10⁻¹⁹ C.
1.60 × 10⁻¹⁹ C mol⁻¹.action: Multiply charge per electron by Avogadro's number to get Faraday's constant.

persistent.gap: You're confusing Faraday's constant with related constants.
persistent.action: Make a constants table: F (96 500 C mol⁻¹), Nₐ (6.02 × 10²³), e (1.60 × 10⁻¹⁹ C).

charge_formula.name: Charge-Moles Relationship
charge_formula.correct: The total charge equals the moles of electrons multiplied by Faraday's constant: Q = n(e⁻) × F.

Q = n(e⁻) / F.error: Dividing instead of multiplying gives charge per mole, not total charge.
Q = n(e⁻) / F.fix: More moles of electrons means MORE charge. Multiply, don't divide.
Q = n(e⁻) / F.action: Units check: mol × C mol⁻¹ = C. Division would give mol² C⁻¹ (nonsense).

Q = n(e⁻) + F.error: You can't add moles and coulombs. Different units.
Q = n(e⁻) + F.fix: The formula is multiplication: Q = n(e⁻) × F.
Q = n(e⁻) + F.action: Adding different units never works. Always multiply or divide in formulas.

Q = F / n(e⁻).error: Inverted relationship. More electrons should give more charge, not less.
Q = F / n(e⁻).fix: Q = n(e⁻) × F. Charge is directly proportional to moles of electrons.
Q = F / n(e⁻).action: Think: 2 moles of electrons carry twice the charge of 1 mole.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding the proportional relationship between charge and moles.
persistent.action: Practise: If n(e⁻) = 0.5 mol, Q = 0.5 × 96 500 = 48 250 C. More moles = more charge.

current_time_formula.name: Current-Time Relationship
current_time_formula.correct: Charge equals current multiplied by time: Q = It, where I is in amperes and t is in seconds.

Q = I/t.error: Dividing gives rate of charge, not total charge.
Q = I/t.fix: Longer time means MORE charge passes. Multiply current by time.
Q = I/t.action: Running a cell for twice as long passes twice as much charge.

Q = I + t.error: You can't add amperes and seconds. Different units.
Q = I + t.fix: Q = I × t. The formula uses multiplication.
Q = I + t.action: Units: A × s = C (ampere-seconds equal coulombs).

Q = t/I.error: Inverted. Higher current should give more charge, not less.
Q = t/I.fix: Q = It. Both higher current AND longer time increase total charge.
Q = t/I.action: Doubling the current doubles the charge (for same time).

persistent.action: Remember: Q = It. 5 A for 100 s = 500 C. 10 A for 100 s = 1000 C. More current = more charge.

time_unit_conversion.name: Time Unit Conversion
time_unit_conversion.correct: Time must be in seconds for Faraday calculations. Convert minutes to seconds (×60) or hours to seconds (×3600).

minutes.error: Time must be in seconds, not minutes.
minutes.fix: Multiply minutes by 60 to convert to seconds before using Q = It.

hours.error: Time must be in seconds, not hours.
hours.fix: Multiply hours by 3600 (60 × 60) to convert to seconds.

milliseconds.error: Time must be in seconds, not milliseconds.
milliseconds.fix: Divide milliseconds by 1000 to convert to seconds.

persistent.gap: You're forgetting to convert time units to seconds.
persistent.action: Always check units first. Circle any time not in seconds and convert before calculating.

current_definition.name: Current Definition
current_definition.correct: Current (I) is the rate of charge flow, measured in amperes. One ampere equals one coulomb per second.

voltage.error: Voltage is potential difference, not rate of charge flow.
voltage.fix: Current = charge per unit time. Voltage = energy per unit charge.
voltage.action: Current (amperes) measures how much charge flows. Voltage (volts) measures the driving force.

resistance.error: Resistance opposes current flow; it doesn't measure flow rate.
resistance.fix: Current = charge flow rate. Resistance = how much the material opposes flow.
resistance.action: Ohm's law: V = IR. Current and resistance are different quantities.

energy.error: Energy is measured in joules, not amperes.
energy.fix: Current measures charge flow (C s⁻¹). Energy measures work done (J).
energy.action: Power = current × voltage. Energy = power × time.

persistent.gap: You're confusing current with other electrical quantities.
persistent.action: Make a table: Current (A) = C/s, Voltage (V) = J/C, Resistance (Ω) = V/A.

electron_mole_ratio.name: Electron-Metal Mole Ratio
electron_mole_ratio.correct: The moles of electrons equals the ionic charge multiplied by moles of metal. For Cu²⁺, 2 mol e⁻ per 1 mol Cu.

1:1 ratio always.error: The ratio depends on the ionic charge, not always 1:1.
1:1 ratio always.fix: Check the half-equation. Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu means 2 mol electrons per mol copper.
1:1 ratio always.action: Al³⁺ + 3e⁻ → Al needs 3 mol electrons. Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag needs only 1.

molar mass determines ratio.error: Molar mass affects mass calculations, not electron ratios.
molar mass determines ratio.fix: The ionic charge determines electrons needed. Molar mass converts moles to grams.
molar mass determines ratio.action: Step 1: Use charge for electron ratio. Step 2: Use molar mass for mass.

equal to atomic number.error: The electron ratio equals ionic charge, not atomic number.
equal to atomic number.fix: Fe²⁺ needs 2e⁻, Fe³⁺ needs 3e⁻. Same element, different ratios.
equal to atomic number.action: Look at the ion charge in the half-equation, not the periodic table.

persistent.gap: You're not using ionic charge to determine electron ratios.
persistent.action: Always write the half-equation first. The coefficient of e⁻ gives you the ratio.

mass_mole_conversion.name: Mass-Mole Conversion
mass_mole_conversion.correct: Moles of a substance equals mass divided by molar mass: n = m/M.

n = M/m.error: Inverted formula. More mass should give more moles, not fewer.
n = M/m.fix: n = m/M. If you have 127 g of Cu and M = 63.5 g mol⁻¹, n = 127/63.5 = 2 mol.
n = M/m.action: Units check: g ÷ (g mol⁻¹) = mol. Correct.

n = m × M.error: Multiplying gives g² mol⁻¹, which has no physical meaning.
n = m × M.fix: n = m/M is a division, not multiplication.
n = m × M.action: Think: 63.5 g of copper = 1 mol. 127 g = 2 mol. You divided.

m = n/M.fix: m = n × M (to find mass). n = m/M (to find moles).
m = n/M.action: Cover what you want, see what's left: want n? Cover n, see m/M.

persistent.gap: You're making algebraic errors with the mole formula.
persistent.action: Use the triangle method: m on top, n and M on bottom. Cover what you want.

faraday_first_law.name: Faraday's First Law
faraday_first_law.correct: Mass deposited is directly proportional to the charge passed. Double the charge deposits double the mass.

m ∝ 1/Q.error: Inverse relationship is wrong. More charge deposits MORE mass.
m ∝ 1/Q.fix: m ∝ Q means directly proportional. More charge = more product.
m ∝ 1/Q.action: Think: run the cell longer (more Q), get more metal deposited.

m ∝ Q².error: It's a linear relationship, not squared.
m ∝ Q².fix: Double the charge exactly doubles the mass. No squaring involved.
m ∝ Q².action: Graph m vs Q: it's a straight line through the origin.

m is independent of Q.error: Mass definitely depends on how much charge passes.
m is independent of Q.fix: The whole point of Faraday's first law: more charge = more product.
m is independent of Q.action: Zero charge = zero product. Charge determines how much forms.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the direct proportionality in Faraday's first law.
persistent.action: Calculate: with 96 500 C, 1 mol e⁻ transfers. With 193 000 C, 2 mol e⁻ transfers. Linear.

faraday_second_law.name: Faraday's Second Law
faraday_second_law.correct: For the same charge passed, moles of product formed is inversely proportional to ionic charge. Higher charge means fewer moles.

n ∝ ionic charge.error: Opposite relationship. Higher ionic charge gives fewer moles, not more.
n ∝ ionic charge.fix: Cu²⁺ needs 2e⁻ per atom. Ag⁺ needs 1e⁻. Same charge deposits twice as many Ag atoms.
n ∝ ionic charge.action: Same charge: 1 mol Ag or 0.5 mol Cu deposited. Inverse relationship.

n is independent of charge.error: Ionic charge absolutely affects how many moles form.
n is independent of charge.fix: The ionic charge determines how many electrons each ion needs.
n is independent of charge.action: Al³⁺ needs 3e⁻, Ag⁺ needs 1e⁻. Same total charge deposits 3× more Ag than Al.

higher charge means more product.error: Higher charge means FEWER moles of product (more electrons per ion).
higher charge means more product.fix: Each Cu²⁺ needs 2 electrons. Each Ag⁺ needs 1. Same electrons produce fewer Cu.
higher charge means more product.action: Imagine: 2 mol electrons produces 2 mol Ag⁺ or 1 mol Cu²⁺.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the inverse relationship in Faraday's second law.
persistent.action: Compare: same charge produces 1 mol Ag (1+), 0.5 mol Cu (2+), 0.33 mol Al (3+).

calculation_steps.name: Four-Step Problem Solving
calculation_steps.formula: n(metal) → n(e⁻) → Q → I or t
calculation_steps.correct: Faraday problems follow four steps: (1) moles of metal, (2) moles of electrons, (3) charge, (4) current or time.

start with charge.error: Order depends on what's given. If given mass, start with moles of metal.
start with charge.fix: Given mass → start with n = m/M. Given current and time → start with Q = It.
start with charge.action: Read the question. What's given? Start there and work toward what's asked.

skip the electron step.error: The electron step connects metal to charge. You can't skip it.
skip the electron step.fix: The half-equation ratio links moles of metal to moles of electrons.
skip the electron step.action: Step 1: moles metal. Step 2: use ratio to find moles electrons. Step 3: Q = nF.

use mass directly in Q = It.error: Q = It doesn't use mass. You need to convert mass to charge first.
use mass directly in Q = It.fix: Mass → moles (n = m/M) → moles e⁻ (ratio) → charge (Q = nF) → then use Q = It.
use mass directly in Q = It.action: Can't shortcut. Each conversion step is necessary.

persistent.gap: You're not following the systematic problem-solving approach.
persistent.action: Write out all four steps for every problem. Label each: moles, electrons, charge, time/current.

yield_actual_vs_theoretical.name: Actual vs Theoretical Yield
yield_actual_vs_theoretical.correct: Actual mass deposited is often less than theoretical due to heat loss, side reactions, or material falling off electrodes.

actual always equals theoretical.error: In practice, actual yield is usually less than calculated.
actual always equals theoretical.fix: Impurities, side reactions, and physical losses reduce actual yield.
actual always equals theoretical.action: Calculate theoretical yield, but expect actual to be 80-95% of that.

actual can exceed theoretical.error: Cannot get more product than stoichiometry allows.
actual can exceed theoretical.fix: Theoretical yield is the maximum. Actual ≤ theoretical always.
actual can exceed theoretical.action: If actual seems higher, check for contamination or measurement error.

temperature doesn't affect yield.error: Temperature affects electrode condition and reaction efficiency.
temperature doesn't affect yield.fix: Higher temperatures can cause product to flake off or side reactions to occur.
temperature doesn't affect yield.action: List factors: electrode surface, temperature, current stability, impurities.

persistent.gap: You're assuming ideal conditions in electrolysis calculations.
persistent.action: Always note: calculated values assume 100% efficiency. Real values are lower.

charge_calculations.instructions: Apply the charge equations to these scenarios.

key_equations.title: Applying Faraday's Equations
key_equations.instructions: Apply the key equations to practical scenarios.

sentences.text: An electroplating cell operates with a current of 3.0 A. To calculate the charge passed in one hour, first convert time: 1 hour = {{d1}} seconds.
With I = 3.0 A and t = 3600 s, the charge Q = {{d2}} C, which represents {{d3}} mol of electrons.
The charge of {{d4}} coulombs per mole of electrons means that transferring 2 mol of electrons requires {{d5}} C.
If you need to pass 50 000 C of charge using a 10 A current, the required time is t = Q/I = {{d6}} seconds.

charge_calculations.title: Charge in Electrolysis Contexts
charge_calculations.instructions: Calculate charge in real electrolysis scenarios.

sentences.text: An aluminium production cell runs at 45 000 A. In one minute ({{d1}} seconds), it passes {{d2}} C of charge.
This charge of 2 700 000 C equals {{d3}} mol of electrons, calculated by dividing by {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: What constant converts charge to moles of electrons?

sentences.text: To determine how long to run a 2.0 A cell to pass 19 300 C, calculate t = 19 300 / 2.0 = {{d5}} seconds, or {{d6}} hours.

mass_calculations.title: Calculating Mass from Charge
mass_calculations.instructions: Work backwards from charge to mass deposited.

sentences.text: A cell passes 9650 C. This equals {{d1}} mol of electrons. For silver (Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag), this deposits {{d2}} mol of Ag.
With M(Ag) = 107.87 g mol⁻¹, the mass deposited is m = n × M = 0.10 × 107.87 = {{d3}} g.
For copper (Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu), the same 0.10 mol of electrons deposits only {{d4}} mol of Cu, because each Cu²⁺ needs {{d5}} electrons.
With M(Cu) = 63.55 g mol⁻¹, this gives m = 0.05 × 63.55 = {{d6}} g, which is {{d7}} than the silver mass.

d7.tooltip: Higher ionic charge means less or more product?

problem_solving.title: Complete Problem Solving
problem_solving.instructions: Work through complete Faraday's Law problems.

sentences.text: To deposit 10.0 g of nickel (M = 58.69 g mol⁻¹), first find moles: n = 10.0/58.69 = {{d1}} mol.
For Ni²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Ni, moles of electrons = 0.170 × 2 = {{d2}} mol. The charge needed is Q = {{d3}} × 96 500.

d3.tooltip: Use moles of electrons, not moles of metal

sentences.text: The charge Q = 0.340 × 96 500 = {{d4}} C. At 3.0 A, the time required is t = Q/I = {{d5}} seconds.
Converting to minutes: 10 937 s ÷ 60 = {{d6}} minutes, or approximately {{d7}} hours.

key_equations.title: Equation Mastery
key_equations.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of Faraday's Law equations.

sentences.text: A student incorrectly wrote Q = n(e⁻)/F. This error would give a charge value that is {{d1}} than the correct value, because the relationship should be {{d2}}.
The constant 96 500 C mol⁻¹ is related to Avogadro's number and the charge on one electron: F = {{d3}} × 1.60 × 10⁻¹⁹ C.

d3.tooltip: Number of electrons in one mole

sentences.text: When Q = It is rearranged to find current, I = Q/t. If a student uses minutes instead of seconds, the calculated current will be {{d4}} times too {{d5}}.

d5.tooltip: Smaller denominator (minutes) gives larger or smaller result?

sentences.text: The unit of current (ampere) can be written as {{d6}}, showing that current measures the {{d7}} of charge flow.

d7.tooltip: Current is charge per unit time

charge_calculations.instructions: Apply charge calculations to more complex problems.

d2.tooltip: If current doubles, time must halve for same Q

mass_calculations.title: Comparing Products
mass_calculations.instructions: Compare mass deposits for different metals.

sentences.text: Same charge through Ag⁺, Cu²⁺, and Al³⁺ solutions deposits moles in ratio 6:3:2 because the inverse of their charges is {{d1}}.
This demonstrates Faraday's {{d2}} law: moles of product is {{d3}} proportional to ionic charge.

d3.tooltip: Higher ionic charge means fewer moles

If 0.10 mol e⁻ deposits 10.8 g of Ag but only 0.90 g of Al, the efficiency difference is due to the {{d6}}, not calculation error.

d6.tooltip: 3 e⁻ per Al³⁺ vs 1 e⁻ per Ag⁺

problem_solving.title: Multi-Step Problem Mastery
problem_solving.instructions: Solve complex problems requiring all steps.

If only 48.0 g of Cr is actually deposited, the percentage yield is (48.0/52.0) × 100 = {{d7}}%, indicating some {{d8}} occurred.

faraday_constant_definition.title: Faraday's Constant
faraday_constant_definition.content: Faraday's constant (F) is the total electric charge carried by one mole of electrons. Its value is 96 500 C mol⁻¹. This constant bridges the gap between the microscopic world of electrons and the macroscopic measurements we make in the laboratory. It equals Avogadro's number multiplied by the charge on a single electron: F = Nₐ × e = 6.02 × 10²³ × 1.60 × 10⁻¹⁹ C ≈ 96 500 C mol⁻¹.
keyPoints: Represents charge per mole of electrons
F = Avogadro's number × charge per electron
Essential for converting between charge and moles

charge_formula.title: Charge-Moles Relationship
charge_formula.content: The equation Q = n(e⁻) × F connects the charge passed through a cell to the moles of electrons transferred. This is a direct proportional relationship: doubling the moles of electrons doubles the charge. To find moles of electrons from charge, rearrange to n(e⁻) = Q/F.

current_time_formula.title: Current-Time Relationship
current_time_formula.content: The equation Q = It shows that charge equals current multiplied by time. Current (I) is measured in amperes (A), and time (t) must be in seconds (s) for the equation to give charge in coulombs. This equation can be rearranged to find current (I = Q/t) or time (t = Q/I).
keyPoints: Always convert time to seconds before calculating

time_unit_conversion.title: Time Unit Conversions
time_unit_conversion.content: Time must always be in seconds for Faraday calculations. Common conversions: 1 minute = 60 seconds, 1 hour = 3600 seconds. Forgetting to convert is a common error that leads to answers that are off by factors of 60 or 3600.
keyPoints: Convert at the start of the problem

current_definition.title: Electric Current
current_definition.content: Current is the rate of flow of electric charge. It is measured in amperes (A), where 1 ampere equals 1 coulomb of charge passing a point per second (1 A = 1 C s⁻¹). Higher current means more charge flows in the same time, resulting in faster electrolysis and more product formed.

electron_mole_ratio.title: Electron-to-Metal Mole Ratios
electron_mole_ratio.content: The half-equation for the electrode reaction tells you how many moles of electrons are needed per mole of metal deposited. For Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu, 2 mol electrons deposit 1 mol copper. For Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag, 1 mol electrons deposit 1 mol silver. The ionic charge determines this ratio.
keyPoints: Higher charge = more electrons per atom

mass_mole_conversion.title: Mass-Mole Conversions
mass_mole_conversion.content: The equation n = m/M converts between mass (in grams) and moles, where M is the molar mass from the periodic table. This is used at the start of problems (given mass, find moles) or at the end (calculated moles, find mass). Remember: m = n × M to find mass.
keyPoints: M = molar mass in g mol⁻¹

faraday_first_law.title: Faraday's First Law
faraday_first_law.content: Faraday's first law states that the mass of substance deposited or dissolved at an electrode is directly proportional to the quantity of charge passed. This means doubling the charge doubles the mass deposited. Mathematically: m ∝ Q.

faraday_second_law.title: Faraday's Second Law
faraday_second_law.content: Faraday's second law states that when the same quantity of charge passes through different electrolytes, the moles of substance deposited are inversely proportional to the ionic charge. Higher charge ions require more electrons per atom, so fewer atoms are deposited.
keyPoints: Same charge: Ag⁺ deposits more moles than Cu²⁺
Same charge: Cu²⁺ deposits more moles than Al³⁺
Ratio for same Q: 6 mol Ag : 3 mol Cu : 2 mol Al

calculation_steps.title: Four-Step Problem Solving
calculation_steps.content: Faraday's Law problems are solved systematically: (1) Convert mass to moles using n = m/M, (2) Use the half-equation ratio to find moles of electrons, (3) Calculate charge using Q = n(e⁻) × F, (4) Find current or time using Q = It. Work backwards if starting from current and time.
keyPoints: Step 4: Charge → current or time (Q = It)

yield_actual_vs_theoretical.title: Actual vs Theoretical Yield
yield_actual_vs_theoretical.content: Calculations give the theoretical yield assuming perfect conditions. In practice, actual yield is typically less due to heat losses, side reactions, impurities in solutions, product flaking off electrodes, or variations in current. Percentage yield = (actual/theoretical) × 100%.
keyPoints: Losses from heat, side reactions, impurities
